(nowadays the [[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]]) | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_aired = December 11, 1956 | last_aired = 1959 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = }}
'''100.000 of niets''' (''100,000 or nothing'') was a [[Flanders|Flemish]] TV quiz, broadcast on the Flemish [[public service]] TV station N.I.R. (nowadays the [[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie|VRT]]), between 1956 and 1959 on Sunday evenings. It was one of the most popular TV shows from the Flemish pioneer years.
==Concept==
"100.000 of niets" was originally part of another quiz, "Knal, wie vangt de bal?" ("Bang, who catches the ball?").<ref name=manu>ADRIAENS, Manu, Blijven kijken! 50 jaar televisie in Vlaanderen, Uitgeverij Lannoo, Tielt, 2003, blz. 147-148.</ref> It aired on December 11, 1956 and by January 12, 1958 it became an independent weekly show. The show was hosted by Tony Corsari, Bob Van Bael and Pros Verbruggen and the jury was hosted by Mr. Van Hove, professor Lucien De Smet and Dr. A.J. Aernouts. In 1959 the show was cancelled. In 1968 it returned to the screen, presented by Pros Verbruggen, Jan Theys and Rudy Samson. Regine Clauwaert was the female guest host.<ref name=manu/>
Each show had three candidates and four thematical rounds. One candidate remained in the finale and had to answer one very detailed question correctly. The prize was 100.000 Belgian francs, though most of the time the winner just received a kitchen device.<ref name=manu/>
==Controversy==
While the show was popular quite some candidates criticized the correct answers needed. On March 9, 1958, one candidate named Van Cuyck lost after giving only one wrong answer in a series of seven correct ones. According to present-day norms many questions were phrased in an ambiguous manner and since every round the acceptance of dubious answers tended to differ at times.<ref name=manu/> One time a candidate complained that his answer was indeed correct, despite being told it wasn't. Host Tony Corsari personally made sure that the man received his award after all.<ref name=manu/>
Female host [[Liliane Taelemans]] received a lot of criticism because her clothes were considered to be "too revealing". She was eventually fired and in 1958 she went on to become the Belgian candidate for the [[Miss Universe]] election.<ref name=manu/>
==In popular culture== * In ''[[The Adventures of Nero]]'' album "De Witte Parel" ("The White Pearl") (1962) [[Nero (comic book character)|Nero]] is a contestant on "100.000 of Niets". The host is a caricature of Tony Corsari.<ref>AUWERA, Fernand and DE SMET, Jan, "Marc Sleen", Standaard Uitgeverij, 1985.</ref>
==Sources== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * http://www.radiovisie.eu/be/nieuws.rvsp?art=68265{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0296293/

{{Infobox journal | title = African Music | image = African_Music_(journal)_cover_image.jpg | former_name = | abbreviation = Afr. Music | discipline = [[Ethnomusicology]] | editors = Lee Watkins | publisher = [[International Library of African Music]] | country = | history = 1954-current | frequency = Annual | openaccess = [[Delayed open access journal|Delayed]], two-years | license = | impact = | impact-year = | ISSN = 0065-4019 | eISSN = 2524-2741 | CODEN = | JSTOR = 00654019 | LCCN = 60045755 | OCLC = 1036109 | website = http://journal.ru.ac.za/index.php/africanmusic/index | link1 = http://journal.ru.ac.za/index.php/africanmusic/issue/current | link1-name = Online access | link2 = http://journal.ru.ac.za/index.php/africanmusic/issue/archive | link2-name = Online archive }} '''''African Music''''' is an annual [[peer-reviewed]]ed [[academic journal]] published by the [[International Library of African Music]]. It covers contextualized studies of [[Music of Africa|African music]] and related arts. Articles are made freely accessible after a two-year embargo period.<ref>{{cite news |last1=South African Cultural Observatory |title=ILAM offers open access to African Music Journal |url=https://www.southafricanculturalobservatory.org.za/article/ilam-offers-open-access-to-african-music-journal |accessdate=28 November 2018 |publisher=South African Cultural Observatory |date=28 March 2017}}</ref>
==History== The journal was established by [[Hugh Tracey]] in 1954,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Open Music Library |title=Journals: African Music |url=https://openmusiclibrary.org/journal/african-music/ |website=Openmusiclibrary |publisher=Alexander Street |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> in the same year as the [[International Library of African Music]]. Tracey was the first [[editor-in-chief]] until his death in 1977.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Thram |first1=Diane |title=From the editor |journal=African Music: Journal of the International Library of African Music |date=2007 |volume=8 |issue=1 |page=4–5 |doi=10.21504/amj.v8i1.1708}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=History: Hugh Tracey founds the Int'l Library of African Music (ILAM) |url=https://www.kalimbamagic.com/info/history/22-hugh-tracey-founds-the-int-l-library-of-african-music-ilam |publisher=Kalimba Magic |accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> Publication was interrupted from 2000 until 2007. Since it was re-launched in 2007, the journal includes a collection of music performances and audio examples relating to articles published within the respective issues.<ref>{{cite web |title=About the journal |website=International Library of African Music |url=http://journal.ru.ac.za/index.php/africanmusic/about |publisher=[[Rhodes University]] |accessdate=19 July 2018}}</ref>
===Editors-in-chief=== The following persons are or have been editor-in-chief of the journal: *1954–1977: [[Hugh Tracey]] *1977–1999: [[Andrew Tracey]] *2007–2016: Diane Thram *2017–current: Lee Watkins
==Abstracting and indexing== The journal is abstracted and indexed in:<ref>{{MIAR|0065-4019}}</ref> *[[Academic Search Premier]] *[[International Bibliography of the Social Sciences]] *[[Modern Language Association Database]] *[[Music Index]] *[[Répertoire International de Littérature Musicale]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://journal.ru.ac.za/index.php/africanmusic/index}}

{{italic title}} {{refimprove|date=July 2015}} '''''Ancient India''''' was a bi-annual and later, annual bulletin published by the [[Archaeological Survey of India]] (ASI) from 1946 to 1966.<ref>{{cite book |title=Aspects of Ancient Indian Technology |page=6 |first=Hari |last=C. Bharadwaj |publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ. |isbn=8120830407|year=1979}}</ref> It replaced the ''Annual Report'' that had previously been published by the Survey.<ref name=RCM>{{cite book|last1=Majumdar|first1=R.C.|title=Ancient India|date=2007|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ.|location=Delhi|isbn=8120804368|page=500|edition=Reprinted.|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=XNxiN5tzKOgC}}</ref>
Established in January 1946 by [[Sir Mortimer Wheeler]] during his tenure as Director-General of the ASI, ''Ancient India'' was published with an aim to "interest the educated Indian public in current work relating to the exploration and conservation of their great heritage of material culture" as well as to "provide technical matter primarily of interest to the archaeologist".<ref name=TAJ>{{cite journal|last1=Fox|first1=Cyril|last2=Childe|first2=V. G.|title=Ancient India: Bulletin of the Archaeological Survey of India, Number 1, January 1946.|journal=The Antiquaries Journal|date=8 January 2012|volume=26|issue=3-4|pages=193–195|doi=10.1017/S0003581500050009}}<!--|accessdate=3 July 2015--></ref> The journal quickly gained a reputation for its heavily illustrated and detailed excavation reports.<ref>{{cite book |title=Sir Mortimer Wheeler |first=Ronald William| last=Clarke |page=84 |publisher=Phoenix House |year=1960}}</ref>
Some of the important archaeological discoveries reported in ''Ancient India'' include Wheeler's excavations at [[Indus Valley Civilization|Indus Valley sites]] and [[Arikamedu]] and the excavation of [[South India]]n [[Stone Age]] and [[megalithic]] sites at [[Brahmavalli]], [[Chandragiri]], [[Maski]] and [[Porkalam]] during the 1950s. The journal also contained scholarly articles on archaeology and epigraphy. On the centenary of the founding of the ASI in 1961, the journal carried a short commemorative piece on the history of the Archaeological Survey of India authored by [[Sourindranath Roy]]. The work was later expanded and published as a book the same year. After publishing 22 volumes, ''Ancient India'' was discontinued in 1966.
A new series of ''Ancient India'' was published in 2011.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://asi.nic.in/asi_publ_ancient_india.asp ''Ancient India'' issue list] by the ASI * [http://www.southasiaarchive.com/Content/sarf.120094 ''Ancient India'' in South Asia Archive] * [http://asi.nic.in/asi_publ_annual_reports.asp ''Annual Report'' list] by the ASI

{{Orphan|date=December 2012}}
In [[anthropology]], '''anthropopoiesis''' is the self-building process of social man and of a whole culture, particularly referred to what concerns modifications of socialized body. The concept found applications mainly in French and Italian contemporary literatures.
In accordance with theoretic background which supports the idea, man is an unfinished being or better his behaviour is not strongly prefixed by genetic heritage. Human beings become fully finished only by means of culture acquisition.
Anthropopoiesis is both anthropogenesis (man “reborn” as social creature) and manufacturing of ”mankind patterns and fictions”. Therefore social and cultural practices build up the man by means of ritual and institutional constraints.
An example could be circumcision, a practice widely existing in many rites of passage amongst Islamic and Jewish believers and also amongst traditional cultures and communities. Besides, Christians ascribe a clear meaning to the sacred garment and to the tonsure; they are convinced that some sacramental rites mark indelible dispositions. All that affects the body and through this one the perception of one’s own identity and social status.
== Bibliography == *[[Francis Affergan]], [[Silvana Borutti]], [[Claude Calame]], [[Ugo Fabietti]], [[Mondher Kilani]], [[Francesco Remotti]], et al. ''Figure dell'umano. Le rappresentazioni dell'antropologia'', Roma: Meltemi, 2005. *[[Giulio Angioni]], ''Fare, dire, sentire: l'identico e il diverso nelle culture'', Nuoro: Il Maestrale, 2011. *Tatiana Cossu, ''L'arca del tiranno: umano, disumano e sovrumano nella Grecia arcaica'', Cagliari: CUEC, 2009. *[[Clifford Geertz]], ''The transition to Humanity'', in S. Tax (ed.), ''Horizons of Anthropology'', London: Allen and Unwin 1965 *[[Francesco Remotti]], ''Contro l'identità'', Roma: Laterza, 1999 *[[Francesco Remotti]], a cura di. ''Forme di umanità'', Milano: Bruno Mondadori, 2002. [[Category:Anthropology]] [[Category:Psychology]]

{{Refimprove|date=February 2009}} {{Infobox music genre |name=Arabesque music |bgcolor=goldenrod |color=white |stylistic_origins={{hlist|[[Byzantine music]]|[[Arabic music]]|[[Middle Eastern music]]|[[Turkish folk music]]}} |cultural_origins=1940s, Turkey |instruments={{hlist|[[Bağlama]]|[[zurna]]|other traditional [[Middle Eastern music#Instruments used|Middle Eastern
instruments]]}} |popularity=Continuous in Turkey, and Middle East in general |derivatives= |subgenrelist= |subgenres={{hlist|Arabesque pop|Arabesque rock|technobesque}} |fusiongenres= |regional_scenes= |other_topics=[[Ottoman classical music]] }} {{Music of Turkey sidebar}} '''Arabesque''' or '''Arabesk''' ({{lang-tr|Arabesk}}) is a term created by [[Turkey|Turkish]] musicologists for an Arabic style of music created in Turkey. The genre was particularly popular in Turkey in the decades from the 1960s through the 1990s. As with Arabic music itself, its aesthetics have evolved over the decades. Although melodies and rhythms are predominantly [[Byzantine music|Byzantine]] and Arabic influenced, it also draws ideas from other aspects of [[Music of Southeastern Europe|Balkan]] and [[Middle Eastern music]], including [[bağlama]] music and Ottoman forms of [[Music of Asia|oriental music]]. Arabesque music are mostly in a minor key, typically in the [[Phrygian mode]], and themes tend to focus on longing, melancholy, strife and love issues. ==Description and history== A very small percentage of Arabesk is exclusively instrumental. For the great majority of it, a singer lies at the center of the music. Male singers dominated the genre in its early years, but female singers probably predominated during its peak years of popularity. Simultaneously with the influx of female singers, the sound grew more dancey and upbeat.{{cite web|url=http://tarkandeluxe.blogspot.com/2004/05/turkish-music-and-artists.html#arab|title=Turkish Music and Artists: Arabesque|work=Yildirim, Ali. Tarkan DeLuxe, 2006 |accessdate=March 21, 2006}} [[Orhan Gencebay]] is generally considered the founder of the genre (though he disagrees with the usage of the term). Other well known older singers are [[Müslüm Gürses]], [[Ferdi Tayfur]] and Hakkı Bulut. One of the most prolific and commercially successful is [[İbrahim Tatlıses]], who broke all sales records in Turkey in 1978 and continues to turn out popular music to this day. He has maintained popularity in the Arabesk scene in recent years through remixing his tracks into dance-friendly club tracks. The pure Arabesk album "Acıların Kadını" (tr: woman of pains) by the singer [[Bergen (singer)|Bergen]] was the bestselling album in Turkey in 1986 and may be fairly labelled one of the classic albums of the genre. Bergen had several other hit Arabesk albums during the 1980s. Other singers include [[Gülben Ergen]], [[Ebru Gundes|Ebru Gündeş]], [[Seda Sayan]], [[Sibel Can]]. The singers [[Muazzez Ersoy]] and [[Bülent Ersoy]] designate themselves as modern exponents of [[Ottoman classical music]]. [[Zerrin Özer]] also made arabesque albums between 1982 and 1988, including her album named "Mutluluklar Dilerim" released in 1984. One of the important names of arabesque music who died in 2012 was [[Azer Bülbül]]. A common theme in Arabesque songs is the highly embellished and agonizing depiction of love and yearning, along with unrequited love, grief and pain. This theme had undertones of class differences in early 1960-70s, during which most of the genre's followers -mostly working class to lower middle class - identified themselves with. Turkish composer [[Fazıl Say]] has repeatedly condemned and criticized Arabesque genre, equating the practice of listening to Arabesque "tantamount to treason". ==See also== *[[Kanto (music)|Kanto]] *[[Byzantine music]] *[[Skiladiko]] *[[Mizrahi music]] *[[Filmi]] *[[Longa (Middle Eastern music)]] ==References== ==External links== *{{cite web|url=http://www.qantara.de/webcom/show_article.php/_c-301/_nr-75/_p-1/i.html|title=Bassturk, Muhabbet, Tarkan & Co. The German-Turkish Pop Scene|work=Bax, Daniel. Qantara.de, 2006 (Translation from German: Nancy Joyce)|accessdate=April 21, 2006}} *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0459242/ "Crossing The Bridge" (documentary film) on IMDb] *[http://ghaneli.net/ "Arabic Music"] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=5C_aAAAAMAAJ&dq=Arabesk+debate&hl=en&ei=JUbFTpiGCYe68gOxoa3bAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA "The arabesk debate: music and musicians in modern Turkey" by Martin Stokes on Google Books] {{Middle Eastern music}} {{Balkan music}} [[Category:20th-century music genres]] [[Category:Turkish music|Folk]] [[Category:Middle Eastern culture]] [[Category:Turkish culture]] [[Category:Middle Eastern music]] [[Category:World music genres]]

{{About|the historian}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox scholar |name = Bernard Lewis |image = Bernard Lewis in 2012 (2).JPG |caption = Bernard Lewis in 2012 |alt = |fullname = |other_names = |birth_date = {{Birth date|mf=yes|1916|5|31}}<ref name="EncyclopediaArts"/> |birth_place = [[London]], England |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2018|5|19|1916|5|31}} |death_place = [[Voorhees Township, New Jersey]], U.S. |region = |school_tradition = |main_interests = [[Oriental studies]], [[Western philosophy]], Middle Eastern philosophy |notable_ideas = |major_works = {{unbulleted list | ''[[The Jews of Islam]]'' {{small|(1984)}} | ''[[Islam and the West]]'' {{small|(1993)}} | ''[[What Went Wrong?]]'' {{small|(2002)}}}} |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |influences = |influenced = [[Heath W. Lowry]], [[Fouad Ajami]] }} '''Bernard Lewis''', [[Fellow of the British Academy|FBA]] (31 May 1916 – 19 May 2018) was a [[British American]] historian specializing in [[oriental studies]].<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Bernard Lewis, Scholar and Political Advisor, Dead At 101 |url=https://www.jpost.com/Breaking-News/Bernard-Lewis-scholar-and-political-advisor-dead-at-101-557881 |work=[[Jerusalem Post]] |location=Jerusalem |date=20 May 2018 |access-date=20 May 2018 }}</ref> He was also known as a [[public intellectual]] and [[pundit (expert)|political commentator]]. Lewis was the Cleveland E. Dodge [[Emeritus|Professor Emeritus]] of Near Eastern Studies at [[Princeton University]]. Lewis' expertise was in the [[history of Islam]] and the interaction between Islam and the West. He was also noted in academic circles for his works on the [[history of the Ottoman Empire]].<ref name="EH">{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Historians and Historical Writing|title=Bernard Lewis|first=Martin|last=Kramer|authorlink=|publisher=Fitzroy Dearborn|location=London|year=1999|volume=1|pages=719–20|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.martinkramer.org%2Fsandbox%2Freader%2Farchives%2Fbernard-lewis%2F&date=2010-11-13|url=http://www.geocities.com/martinkramerorg/BernardLewis.htm|archivedate=13 November 2010|accessdate=23 May 2006}}</ref>
Lewis served as a soldier in the British Army in the [[Royal Armoured Corps]] and [[Intelligence Corps (United Kingdom)|Intelligence Corps]] during the [[Second World War]] before being seconded to the [[Foreign Office]]. After the war, he returned to the [[School of Oriental and African Studies]] at the [[University of London]] and was appointed to the new chair in [[Near East|Near]] and Middle Eastern History.
In 2007 and 1999, respectively, Lewis was called "the West's leading interpreter of the Middle East"<ref name=Abrahmson2007>{{cite web|last1=Abrahmson|first1=James L.|title=Will the West – and the United States – Go the Distance?|url=http://www.unc.edu/depts/diplomat/item/2007/0406/ed_distance.html|website=[[American Diplomacy]]|accessdate=16 February 2015|date=8 June 2007}}</ref> and "the most influential postwar historian of Islam and the Middle East".<ref name="EH" /> His advice was frequently sought by [[neoconservative]] policymakers, including the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Weisberg|first1=Jacob|title=AEI's weird celebration|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/the_big_idea/2007/03/party_of_defeat.html|accessdate=16 February 2015|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=14 March 2007}}</ref> However, his support of the [[Iraq War]] and [[neoconservative]] ideals have since come under scrutiny.<ref>[http://forward.com/news/163089/neocons-gather-to-fete-iraq-war-godfather-bernard/ Neocons Gather To Fete Iraq War Godfather Bernard Lewis], ''[[The Forward]]''</ref><ref>[http://mondoweiss.net/2012/04/bernard-lewis-revises-bernard-lewis-says-he-opposed-invasion-of-iraq/ Bernard Lewis revises Bernard Lewis (says he opposed invasion of Iraq!)], ''[[Mondoweiss]]''</ref><ref>[http://www.thenational.ae/arts-lifestyle/the-review/how-neoconservatives-led-us-to-war-in-iraq How neoconservatives led US to war in Iraq], ''[[The National (Abu Dhabi)]]''</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Migdal | first = Joel | title = Shifting Sands the United States in the Middle East | publisher = Columbia University Press | location = New York | year = 2014 | isbn = 9780231536349 |page = 241 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Ahmad | first = Muhammad | title = The road to Iraq : the making of a neoconservative war | publisher = Edinburgh University Press | location = Edinburgh | year = 2014 | isbn = 9780748693054 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=SX9KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT101&dq=Bernard+Lewis+neoconservative#v=onepage&q=Bernard%20Lewis%20neoconservative&f=false }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Chaudet | first = Didier | title = When Empire Meets Nationalism : Power Politics in the US and Russia | publisher = Routledge | location = City | year = 2016 | isbn = 978-1134762538 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=P_aNCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT170&dq=Bernard+Lewis+neoconservative#v=onepage&q=Bernard%20Lewis%20neoconservative&f=false }}</ref>
Lewis was also notable for his public debates with [[Edward Said]], who accused Lewis and other [[orientalists]] of misrepresenting Islam and serving the purposes of imperialist domination,<ref name="said"/> to which Lewis responded by defending Orientalism as a facet of humanism and accusing Said of politicizing the subject.<ref name="EH"/><ref>{{cite journal|journal=New York Review of Books|title=Orientalism: An Exchange|authors=Edward W. Said and Oleg Grabar, reply by Bernard Lewis|date=12 Aug 1982|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/1982/08/12/orientalism-an-exchange/}}</ref> Lewis argued that the deaths of the [[Armenian Genocide]] resulted from a struggle between two nationalistic movements<ref name=suny>{{cite book|title=A Question of Genocide: Armenians and Turks at the End of the Ottoman Empire|publisher=Oxford University Press|editors=Ronald Grigor Suny, Fatma Müge Göçek, Norman M. Naimark|year=2011|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q_mHshUAeZ8C&pg=PA31|page=31|isbn=9780199781041}}</ref> and that there is no proof of intent by the Ottoman government to exterminate the Armenian nation.<ref name=pbs>{{cite web|last1=Getler|first1=Michae|title=Documenting and Debating a 'Genocide'|url=https://www.pbs.org/ombudsman/2006/04/documenting_and_debating_a_genocide.html|website=PBS|accessdate=21 February 2015|date=21 April 2006}}</ref> These views prompted a number of scholars to accuse Lewis of [[genocide denial]] and resulted in a successful civil lawsuit against him in a French court.<ref>http://www.voltairenet.org/article14133.html</ref>
==Family and personal life== Bernard Lewis was born to middle-class [[Jew]]ish parents, Harry Lewis and the former Jane Levy,<ref name=EncyclopediaArts>{{cite web|url=https://www.encyclopedia.com/arts/educational-magazines/lewis-bernard-1916|title=Lewis, Bernard 1916- - Dictionary definition of Lewis, Bernard 1916- - Encyclopedia.com: FREE online dictionary|website=www.encyclopedia.com}}</ref> in [[Stoke Newington]], London. He became interested in languages and history while preparing for his [[bar mitzvah]].{{sfn|Lewis|2004|pp= 1–2}}
Lewis became a naturalized citizen of the United States in 1982. In 1947 he married Ruth Hélène Oppenhejm, with whom he had a daughter and a son. Their marriage was dissolved in 1974.<ref name="EH"/>
==Academic career== In 1936, Lewis graduated from the School of Oriental Studies (now [[School of Oriental and African Studies]], SOAS) at the [[University of London]] with a [[bachelor's degree|BA]] in history with special reference to the [[Near East|Near]] and Middle East. He earned his PhD three years later, also from SOAS, specializing in the history of [[Islam]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Bernard Lewis Cleveland E. Dodge Professor of Near Eastern Studies, Emeritus |url=https://www.princeton.edu/~nes/faculty_lewis.html |website=University of Princeton |accessdate=26 May 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060516012512/http://www.princeton.edu/~nes/faculty_lewis.html |archivedate=16 May 2006 |df= }}</ref> Lewis also studied law, going part of the way toward becoming a solicitor, but returned to study Middle Eastern history. He undertook post-graduate studies at the [[University of Paris]], where he studied with the orientalist [[Louis Massignon]] and earned the "Diplôme des Études Sémitiques" in 1937.<ref name="EH"/> He returned to SOAS in 1938 as an assistant lecturer in Islamic History.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/3602621/Profile-Professor-Bernard-Lewis.html|title=Profile: Professor Bernard Lewis|publisher=Telegraph|date=15 February 2004|accessdate=20 May 2018}}</ref>
During the [[Second World War]], Lewis served in the British Army in the [[Royal Armoured Corps]] and as a [[Corporal]] in the [[Intelligence Corps (United Kingdom)|Intelligence Corps]] in 1940–41 before being seconded to the [[Foreign Office]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sugarman|first1=Martin|title=Breaking the codes; Jewish personnel at Bletchley Park|url=http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/resources/filer.rhtm/595696/breaking+the+codes-+jewish+personnel+at+bletchley+park.pdf|website=Bletchley Park|accessdate=19 February 2015|date=6 October 2008}}</ref> After the war, he returned to SOAS. In 1949, at the age of 33, he was appointed to the new chair in Near and Middle Eastern History.{{sfn|Lewis|2004|pp=3–4}}
In 1974, aged 57, Lewis accepted a joint position at [[Princeton University]] and the [[Institute for Advanced Study]], also located in [[Princeton, New Jersey]]. The terms of his appointment were such that Lewis taught only one semester per year, and being free from administrative responsibilities, he could devote more time to research than previously. Consequently, Lewis's arrival at Princeton marked the beginning of the most prolific period in his research career during which he published numerous books and articles based on previously accumulated materials.{{sfn|Lewis|2004|pp=6–7}} After retiring from Princeton in 1986, Lewis served at [[Cornell University]] until 1990.<ref name="EH"/>
[[File:Robert Wistrich and Bernard Lewis.jpg|thumb|left|Bernard Lewis in 2007]] In 1966, Lewis was a founding member of the [[learned society]], [[Middle East Studies Association of North America]] (MESA), but in 2007 he broke away and founded [[Association for the Study of the Middle East and Africa]] (ASMEA) to challenge MESA, which the ''[[New York Sun]]'' noted as "dominated by academics who have been critical of Israel and of America's role in the Middle East".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Karni|first1=Annie|title=Group formed to improve Middle East scholarship|url=http://www.nysun.com/new-york/group-formed-to-improve-middle-east-scholarship/66110/|accessdate=19 February 2015|work=The New York Sun|date=8 November 2007}}</ref> The organization was formed as an academic society dedicated to promoting high standards of research and teaching in Middle Eastern and African studies and other related fields, with Lewis as Chairman of its academic council.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asmeascholars.org/|title=About ASMEA|publisher=ASMEA|date=20 May 2018}}</ref>
In 1990, the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] selected Lewis for the [[Jefferson Lecture]], the U.S. federal government's highest honor for achievement in the [[humanities]]. His lecture, entitled "Western Civilization: A View from the East", was revised and reprinted in ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]'' under the title "The Roots of Muslim Rage."<ref>{{cite web|title=Jefferson Lecture|url=http://www.neh.gov/about/awards/jefferson-lecture|website=The National Endowment for the Humanities|accessdate=19 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Lewis|first1=Bernard|title=The roots of Muslim rage|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1990/09/the-roots-of-muslim-rage/304643/|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=19 February 2015|date=1 September 1990}}</ref> His 2007 [[Irving Kristol Lecture]], given to the [[American Enterprise Institute]], was published as ''Europe and Islam''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aei.org/publication/the-2007-irving-kristol-lecture-by-bernard-lewis/|title=The 2007 Irving Kristol Lecture by Bernard Lewis|publisher=AEI|accessdate=20 May 2018}}</ref>
==Research== Lewis' influence extends beyond academia to the general public. He was a pioneer of the social and economic history of the Middle East and is famous for his extensive research of the [[Ottoman archives]].<ref name="EH"/> He began his research career with the study of [[Middle Ages|medieval]] Arab, especially Syrian, history.<ref name="EH"/> His first article, dedicated to professional [[guild]]s of medieval Islam, had been widely regarded as the most authoritative work on the subject for about thirty years.<ref name="Humphreys">{{cite journal|first=R. Stephen|last=Humphreys|journal=Humanities|title=Bernard Lewis: An Appreciation|volume= 11|issue=3|date=May–June 1990|pages=17–20|url=https://docs.google.com/document/pub?id=1YRNmBFbo4R32F3j9QChFTPdTi8TIa0_D6ZQ1D45vhAE|accessdate=20 February 2015}}</ref> However, after the establishment of the state of [[Israel]] in 1948, scholars of Jewish origin found it more and more difficult to conduct archival and field research in Arab countries, where they were suspected of espionage. Therefore, Lewis switched to the study of the [[Ottoman Empire]], while continuing to research Arab history through the Ottoman archives<ref name="EH"/> which had only recently been opened to Western researchers. A series of articles that Lewis published over the next several years revolutionized the history of the Middle East by giving a broad picture of Islamic society, including its government, economy, and demographics.<ref name="Humphreys"/>
Lewis argued that the Middle East is currently backward and its decline was a largely self-inflicted condition resulting from both culture and religion, as opposed to the post-colonialist view which posits the problems of the region as economic and political maldevelopment mainly due to the 19th-century European colonization.{{sfn|Lewis|2004|pp=156–80}} In his 1982 work ''Muslim Discovery of Europe,'' Lewis argues that Muslim societies could not keep pace with the West and that "Crusader successes were due in no small part to Muslim weakness."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lewis|first1=Bernard|title=The Muslim Discovery of Europe|date=2001|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|location=New York|isbn=978-0393321654|page=22}}</ref> Further, he suggested that as early as the 11th century Islamic societies were decaying, primarily the byproduct of internal problems like "cultural arrogance," which was a barrier to creative borrowing, rather than external pressures like the [[Crusades]].<ref name="EH"/>
In the wake of Soviet and Arab attempts to delegitimize Israel as a racist country, Lewis wrote a study of [[anti-Semitism]], ''Semites and Anti-Semites'' (1986).<ref name="EH"/> In other works he argued Arab rage against Israel was disproportionate to other tragedies or injustices in the Muslim world, such as the [[Soviet invasion of Afghanistan]] and control of Muslim-majority land in Central Asia, the bloody and destructive fighting during the [[Hama massacre|Hama uprising in Syria]] (1982), the [[Algerian Civil War]] (1992–1998), and the [[Iran–Iraq War]] (1980–1988).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lewis|first1=Bernard|title=The Crisis of Islam: Holy War and Unholy Terror|date=2004|publisher=Random House Trade Paperbacks|location=New York|isbn=978-0812967852|pages=90–91, 108, 110–11}}</ref> {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage= | video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?167924-1/went-wrong ''Booknotes'' interview with Lewis on ''What Went Wrong?'', December 30, 2001], [[C-SPAN]]<ref name="cspan">{{cite web | title =What Went Wrong| website = | publisher =[[C-SPAN]] | date =30 December 2001 | url =https://www.c-span.org/video/?167924-1/went-wrong| accessdate =25 March 2017 }}</ref> }} In addition to his scholarly works, Lewis wrote several influential books accessible to the general public: ''The Arabs in History'' (1950), ''The Middle East and the West'' (1964), and ''The Middle East'' (1995).<ref name="EH"/> In the wake of the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]], the interest in Lewis's work surged, especially his 1990 essay ''The Roots of Muslim Rage''. Three of his books were published after 9/11: ''[[What Went Wrong?]]'' (written before the attacks), which explored the reasons of the Muslim world's apprehension of (and sometimes outright hostility to) modernization; ''[[The Crisis of Islam]]''; and ''Islam: The Religion and the People''.
===Armenian Genocide=== {{see also|Armenian Genocide denial}}
The first two editions of Lewis' ''The Emergence of Modern Turkey'' (1961 and 1968) describe the [[Armenian Genocide]] as "the terrible holocaust of 1915, when a million and a half Armenians perished".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Karsh|first1=Efraim|title=Islamic Imperialism: A History|date=2007|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Connecticut|isbn=978-0300106039|page=242|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LmZP3mixescC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Islamic+Imperialism:+A+History#v=snippet&q=lewis&f=false|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> In later editions, this text is altered to "the terrible slaughter of 1915, when, according to estimates, more than a million Armenians perished, as well as an unknown number of [[Turkish people|Turks]]".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bostom|first1=Andrew G.|title=Bernard Lewis and Islam|url=http://archive.frontpagemag.com/readArticle.aspx?ARTID=4127|website=FrontPageMagazine|accessdate=21 February 2015|date=6 June 2006|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120709071712/http://archive.frontpagemag.com/readArticle.aspx?ARTID=4127|archive-date=9 July 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In this passage, Lewis argues that the deaths were the result of a struggle for the same land between two competing nationalist movements.<ref name="suny"/>
The change in Lewis' textual description of the [[Armenian Genocide]] and his signing of the petition against the Congressional resolution was controversial among some Armenian historians as well as journalists, who suggested that Lewis was engaging in [[historical revisionism (negationism)|historical revisionism]] to serve his own political and personal interests.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Dadrian|first1=Vahakn N.|title=Warrant for Genocide: Key Elements of Turko-Armenian Conflict|date=2007|publisher=Transaction Publishers|location=New Brunswick, N.J.|isbn=978-0765805591|pages=131}}</ref>
Lewis called the label "genocide" the "Armenian version of this history" in a November 1993 interview with ''[[Le Monde]]'', for which he faced a civil proceeding in a French court.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Le Monde|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/europe/article/2005/04/22/l-historien-bernard-lewis-condamne-pour-avoir-nie-la-realite-du-genocide-armenien_641923_3214.html|title=L'historien Bernard Lewis condamné pour avoir nié la réalité du génocide arménien|date=22 Apr 2005|author=Nathaniel Herzberg}}</ref> In a subsequent exchange on the pages of ''Le Monde'', Lewis wrote that while "terrible atrocities" did occur, "there exists no serious proof of a decision and of a plan of the Ottoman government aiming to exterminate the Armenian nation".<ref>{{cite web|title=Condamnation judiciaire de Bernard Lewis|url=http://www.voltairenet.org/article14133.html|website=Voltaire Network|accessdate=21 February 2015|language=French|date=8 June 2004}}</ref> In reference to both these articles, the court stated that Lewis "failed in his duty of objectivity and prudence in expressing himself without nuance on such a sensitive subject".<ref>{{cite web|title=Condamnation judiciaire de Bernard Lewis|url=http://www.voltairenet.org/article14133.html|website=Voltaire Network|accessdate=21 February 2015|language=French|date=8 June 2004|quote=c’est en occultant les éléments contraires à sa thèse, que le défendeur a pu affirmer qu’il n’y avait pas de "preuve sérieuse" du génocide arménien ; [...] il a ainsi manqué à ses devoirs d’objectivité et de prudence, en s’exprimant sans nuance, sur un sujet aussi sensible (Translation: it is by concealing the elements contrary to his thesis that the defendant could affirm that there was no "serious proof" of the Armenian genocide; [...] he has thus failed in his duty of objectivity and prudence in expressing himself without nuance on such a sensitive subject)}}</ref> He was ordered to pay one [[franc (France)|franc]] as damages for his statements on the Armenian Genocide in Ottoman Turkey.<ref name="Le Monde">{{cite news|title=Les actions engagées par les parties civiles arméniennes contre "le Monde" déclarées irrecevables par le tribunal de Paris|work=Le Monde|date=27 November 1994|language=French}}</ref> Three other court cases against Bernard Lewis failed in the Paris tribunal, including one filed by the Armenian National Committee of France and two filed by [[Jacques Trémollet de Villers]].<ref name="Le Monde"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Lewis Replies|url=https://www.princeton.edu/~paw/archive_old/PAW95-96/16_9596/0605let.html#story3|website=Princeton Alumni Weekly|accessdate=21 February 2015|date=5 June 1996}}</ref>
Lewis' views on the Armenian Genocide were criticized by a number of historians and sociologists, among them [[Alain Finkielkraut]], [[Yves Ternon]], [[Richard G. Hovannisian]], [[Robert Melson]], and [[Pierre Vidal-Naquet]].<ref name=Auron>{{cite book|last1=Auron|first1=Yair|title=The Banality of Denial: Israel and the Armenian Genocide|date=2005|publisher=Transaction Publishers|location=New Brunswick, N.J.|isbn=978-0765808349|page=235}}</ref><ref name=Melson>{{cite book|last1=Melson|first1=Robert|title=Revolution and Genocide: On the Origins of the Armenian Genocide and the Holocaust|date=1992|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0226519906|page=289}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=MacDonald|first1=David B.|title=''Identity Politics in the Age of Genocide: The Holocaust and Historical Representation'|date=2008|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0415430616|page=241}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Finkelstein|first1=Norman G.|title=''The Holocaust Industry: Reflections on the Exploitation of Jewish Suffering|date=2003|publisher=Verso|location=London|isbn=978-1859844885|page=69}}</ref>
Lewis has argued for his denial stance that:{{quote|The meaning of genocide is the planned destruction of a religious and ethnic group, as far as it is known to me, there is no evidence for that in the case of the Armenians. [...] There is no evidence of a decision to massacre. On the contrary, there is considerable evidence of attempts to prevent it, which were not very successful. Yes there were tremendous massacres, the numbers are very uncertain but a million may well be likely...<ref name="ATA">{{cite web|url=http://www.ataa.org/reference/lewis.pdf|title=Statement of Professor Bernard Lewis, Princeton University, "Distinguishing Armenian Case from Holocaust"|publisher=Assembly of Turkish American Associations|date=14 April 2002|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060715105123/http://www.ataa.org/magazine/blewis_statement.pdf|archivedate=15 July 2006|deadurl=no|accessdate=21 February 2015|format=PDF}}</ref> [and] the issue is not whether the massacres happened or not, but rather if these massacres were as a result of a deliberate preconceived decision of the Turkish government... there is no evidence for such a decision.<ref name="pbs"/>}}
Lewis stated that he believed "to make [the Armenian Genocide] a parallel with the Holocaust in Germany" was "rather absurd".<ref name="ATA"/> In an interview with ''[[Ha'aretz]]'', he stated: {{quote|The deniers of Holocaust have a purpose: to prolong Nazism and to return to Nazi legislation. Nobody wants the 'Young Turks' back, and nobody wants to have back the Ottoman Law. What do the Armenians want? The Armenians want to benefit from both worlds. On the one hand, they speak with pride of their struggle against the Ottoman despotism, while on the other hand, they compare their tragedy to the Jewish Holocaust. I do not accept this. I do not say that the Armenians did not suffer terribly. But I find enough cause for me to contain their attempts to use the Armenian massacres to diminish the worth of the Jewish Holocaust and to relate to it instead as an ethnic dispute.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Karpel|first1=Dalia|title=There Was No Genocide: Interview with Prof. Bernard Lewis|url=http://www.ataa.org/reference/karpel.html|accessdate=21 February 2015|work=Ha'aretz Weekly|publisher=Assembly of Turkish American Associations|date=23 January 1998}}</ref>}}
Lewis has been labelled a ''genocide denier'' by [[Stephen Zunes]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Zunes|first1=Stephen|title=US Denial of the Armenian Genocide|url=http://www.commondreams.org/views/2007/10/22/us-denial-armenian-genocide|website=Common Dreams|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> [[Israel Charny]],<ref>[http://www.ideajournal.com/articles.php?id=27 The Psychological Satisfaction of Denials of the Holocaust or Other Genocides by Non-Extremists or Bigots, and Even by Known Scholars], by Israel Charny, "IDEA" journal, 17 July 2001, Vol.6, no.1</ref> [[David B. MacDonald]]<ref>Identity Politics in the Age of Genocide: The Holocaust and Historical Representation, By David B. MacDonald, Routledge, 2008, {{ISBN|0-415-43061-5}}, p. 121</ref> and the [[Armenian National Committee of America]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://asbarez.com/54263/genocide-denier-bernard-lewis-honored-at-white-house-ceremony/|title=Genocide Denier Bernard Lewis Honored at White House Ceremony - Asbarez.com|website=asbarez.com}}</ref> [[Yair Auron]] suggested that "Lewis' stature provided a lofty cover for the Turkish national agenda of obfuscating academic research on the Armenian Genocide".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bostom|first1=Andrew G.|title=The Islamization of Europe|url=http://archive.frontpagemag.com/readArticle.aspx?ARTID=10060|website=FrontPageMagazine|accessdate=21 February 2015|date=31 December 2004|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221145440/http://archive.frontpagemag.com/readArticle.aspx?ARTID=10060|archive-date=21 February 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Israel Charny]] wrote that Lewis' "seemingly scholarly concern ... of Armenians constituting a threat to the Turks as a rebellious force who together with the Russians threatened the Ottoman Empire, and the insistence that only a policy of deportations was executed, barely conceal the fact that the organized deportations constituted systematic mass murder".<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Charny|first1=Israel|title=The Psychological Satisfaction of Denials of the Holocaust or Other Genocides by Non-Extremists or Bigots, and Even by Known Scholars|journal=IDEA|date=17 July 2001|url=http://www.ideajournal.com/articles.php?id=27|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> Charny compares the "logical structures" employed by Lewis in his denial of the genocide to those employed by [[Ernst Nolte]] in his Holocaust [[negationism]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Charny|first1=Israel W.|title=Fighting Suicide Bombing: A Worldwide Campaign for Life|date=2006|publisher=Praeger Security International|location=Westport, Connecticut|isbn=978-0275993368|page=241}}</ref>
When Lewis received the [[National Humanities Medal]] from US President [[George W. Bush]] in November 2006, the [[Armenian National Committee of America]] objected: "The President's decision to honor the work of a known genocide denier—an academic mercenary whose politically motivated efforts to cover up the truth run counter to the very principles this award was established to honor—represents a true betrayal of the public trust."<ref>{{cite web|title=Armenian Genocide Denier Bernard Lewis Awarded National Humanities Medal |url=http://www.anca.org/press_releases/press_releases.php?prid=1024 |publisher=Armenian National Committee of America |accessdate=21 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221133530/http://www.anca.org/press_releases/press_releases.php?prid=1024 |archivedate=21 February 2015 |df= }}</ref>
==Views and influence on contemporary politics== In the mid-1960s, Lewis emerged as a commentator on the issues of the modern Middle East and his analysis of the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict]] and the rise of [[militant Islam]] brought him publicity and aroused significant controversy. American historian [[Joel Beinin]] has called him "perhaps the most articulate and learned Zionist advocate in the North American Middle East academic community".<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Beinin|first1=Joel|title=Review of ''Semites and Anti-Semites: An Inquiry into Conflict and Prejudice'' by Bernard Lewis|journal=MERIP Middle East Report|date=July 1987|issue=147|pages=42–45|doi=10.2307/3011952|jstor=3011952}}</ref> Lewis's policy advice has particular weight thanks to this scholarly authority.<ref name="Humphreys"/> U.S. Vice President [[Dick Cheney]] remarked "in this new century, his wisdom is sought daily by policymakers, diplomats, fellow academics, and the news media".<ref>{{cite web|title=Remarks by Vice President Cheney at the World Affairs Council of Philadelphia Luncheon Honoring Professor Bernard Lewis |publisher=The White House|date=2 May 2006|accessdate=22 February 2015|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2006/05/20060501-3.html}}</ref>
A harsh critic of the [[Soviet Union]], Lewis continued the liberal tradition in Islamic historical studies. Although his early [[marxism|Marxist]] views had a bearing on his first book ''The Origins of Ismailism'', Lewis subsequently discarded Marxism. His later works are a reaction against the left-wing current of [[Third-worldism]] which came to be a significant current in [[Middle Eastern studies]].<ref name="EH"/>
During his career Lewis developed ties with governments around the world: during her time as Prime Minister of Israel, [[Golda Meir]] assigned Lewis' articles as reading to her cabinet members, and during the Presidency of George W. Bush, he advised administration members including Cheney, [[Donald Rumsfeld]] and Bush himself. He was also close to King [[Hussein of Jordan]] and his brother, [[Prince Hassan bin Talal]]. He also had ties to the regime of [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]], the last [[Shah]] of [[Iran]], the Turkish military dictatorship led by [[Kenan Evren]], and the Egyptian government of [[Anwar Sadat]]: he acted as a go-between between the Sadat administration and Israel in 1971 when he relayed a message to the Israeli government regarding the possibility of a peace agreement at the request of Sadat's spokesman Tahasin Bashir.<ref name=abukhalil />
[[File:David Horovitz interviews Bernard Lewis.jpg|thumb|left|[[David Horovitz]] interviewing Bernard Lewis in 2011]] Lewis advocated closer Western ties with Israel and Turkey, which he saw as especially important in light of the extension of the Soviet influence in the Middle East. Modern Turkey holds a special place in Lewis's view of the region due to the country's efforts to become a part of the West.<ref name="EH"/> He was an Honorary Fellow of the [[Institute of Turkish Studies]], an honor which is given "on the basis of generally recognized scholarly distinction and ... long and devoted service to the field of Turkish Studies."<ref>{{cite web |title=About the Institute of Turkish Studies|url=http://www.turkishstudies.org/about/index.shtml|website=Institute of Turkish Studies |accessdate=22 February 2015}}</ref>
Lewis views [[Christendom]] and Islam as civilizations that have been in perpetual collision since the advent of Islam in the 7th century. In his essay ''The Roots of Muslim Rage'' (1990), he argued that the struggle between the West and Islam was gathering strength. According to one source, this essay (and Lewis' 1990 Jefferson Lecture on which the article was based) first introduced the term "[[Islamic fundamentalism]]" to North America.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Haque|first1=Amber|editor1-last=Driel|editor1-first=Barry van|title=Confronting Islamophobia in Educational Practice|date=2004|publisher=Trentham Books|location=Stoke-on-Trent|isbn=978-1858563404|page=6|chapter=Islamophobia in North America: Confronting the Menace}}</ref> This essay has been credited with coining the phrase "[[clash of civilizations]]", which received prominence in the eponymous book by [[Samuel P. Huntington|Samuel Huntington]].<ref name="Ajami">{{cite web|first=Fouad|last=Ajami|authorlink=Fouad Ajami|title=A Sage in Christendom: A Personal Tribute to Bernard Lewis|publisher=[[OpinionJournal]]|date=2 May 2006|accessdate=23 May 2006|url=http://www.opinionjournal.com/editorial/feature.html?id=110008313}}</ref> However, another source indicates that Lewis first used the phrase "clash of civilizations" at a 1957 meeting in Washington where it was recorded in the transcript.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Liebowitz|first1=Ruthie Blum|title=One on One: When Defeat Means Liberation|url=http://www.jpost.com/Magazine/Features/One-on-One-When-defeat-means-liberation|work=Jerusalem Post|date=6 March 2008}}</ref>
In 1998, Lewis read in a London-based newspaper ''[[Al-Quds Al-Arabi]]'' a declaration of war on the United States by [[Osama bin Laden]]. In his essay "A License to Kill", Lewis indicated he considered bin Laden's language as the "ideology of [[jihad]]" and warned that bin Laden would be a danger to the West.<ref name="Ajami"/> The essay was published after the [[Clinton administration]] and the [[US intelligence community]] had begun its hunt for bin Laden in [[Sudan]] and then in [[Afghanistan]].
===Jihad=== Lewis presented some of his conclusions about [[Islamic culture]], [[Shari'a]] law, [[jihad]], and the modern day phenomenon of terrorism in his text ''Islam: The Religion and the People''.{{sfn|Lewis|Churchill|2008|pp=145–50}} He writes of jihad as a distinct "religious obligation", but suggests that "it is a pity" that people engaging in terrorist activities are not more aware of their own religion:
{{quote|Muslim fighters are commanded not to kill women, children, or the aged unless they attack first; not to torture or otherwise ill-treat prisoners; to give fair warning of the opening of hostilities or their resumption after a truce; and to honor agreements. ... At no time did the classical jurists offer any approval or legitimacy to what we nowadays call terrorism. Nor indeed is there any evidence of the use of terrorism as it is practiced nowadays."{{sfn|Lewis|Churchill|2008|pp=151}}}}
In Lewis' view, the "by now widespread terrorism practice of suicide bombing is a development of the 20th century" with "no antecedents in Islamic history, and no justification in terms of Islamic theology, law, or tradition".{{sfn|Lewis|Churchill|2008|p=153}} He further comments that "the fanatical warrior offering his victims the choice of the Koran or the sword is not only untrue, it is impossible" and that "generally speaking, Muslim tolerance of unbelievers was far better than anything available in Christendom, until the rise of secularism in the 17th century".{{sfn|Lewis|Churchill|2008|pp=146}}
This view has been criticised by [[As'ad AbuKhalil]], who noted that: "Methodologically, [Lewis] insists that terrorism by individual Muslims should be considered Islamic terrorism, while terrorism by individual Jews or Christians is never considered Jewish or Christian terrorism."<ref>AbuKhalil, 2004, p. [https://www.scribd.com/document/169838430/bernard-lewis 134]</ref> He also criticised Lewis' understanding of [[Osama bin Laden]], seeing Lewis' interpretation of bin Laden "as some kind of influential Muslim theologian" along the lines of classical theologians like [[Al-Ghazali]], rather than "the terrorist fanatic that he is". AbuKhalil has also criticised the place of Islam in Lewis' worldview more generally, arguing that the most prominent feature of his work was its "theologocentrism" (borrowing a term from [[Maxime Rodinson]]) - that Lewis interprets all aspects of behaviour among Muslims solely through the lens of [[Islamic theology]], subsuming the study of Muslim peoples, their languages, the geographical areas where Muslims predominate, Islamic governments, the governments of Arab countries and [[Sharia]] under the label of "Islam".<ref name=abukhalil />
===Debates with Edward Said=== Lewis was known for his literary debates with [[Edward Said]], the Palestinian American [[Literary theory|literary theorist]] whose aim was to deconstruct what he called [[Orientalism|Orientalist]] scholarship. Said, who was a professor at [[Columbia University]], characterized Lewis' work as a prime example of Orientalism in his 1978 book ''[[Orientalism (book)|Orientalism]]'' and in his later book ''[[Covering Islam]]''. Said asserted that the field of Orientalism was political intellectualism bent on self-affirmation rather than objective study,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Said|first1=Edward W.|title=Orientalism|date=1979|publisher=Vintage Books|location=New York|isbn=978-0394740676|page=12}}</ref> a form of racism, and a tool of [[imperialism|imperialist]] domination.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Windschuttle|first1=Keith|title=Edward Said's "Orientalism" Revisited|journal=The New Criterion|date=January 1999|volume=17|page=30|url=http://www.newcriterion.com/articles.cfm/Edward-Said-s--ldquo-Orientalism-rdquo--revisited-2937|accessdate=27 February 2015}}</ref> He further questioned the scientific neutrality of some leading Middle East scholars, including Lewis, on the [[Arab World]]. In an interview with ''[[Al-Ahram]]'' weekly, Said suggested that Lewis' knowledge of the Middle East was so biased that it could not be taken seriously and claimed "Bernard Lewis hasn't set foot in the Middle East, in the Arab world, for at least 40 years. He knows something about Turkey, I'm told, but he knows nothing about the Arab world."<ref>{{cite news|title=Resources of Hope |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2003/631/focus.htm |accessdate=27 February 2015 |work=Al-Ahram Weekly |issue=631 |date=2 April 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221221020/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2003/631/focus.htm |archivedate=21 February 2015 }}</ref> Said considered that Lewis treats Islam as a monolithic entity without the nuance of its plurality, internal dynamics, and historical complexities, and accused him of "demagogy and downright ignorance".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Said|first1=Edward W.|title=The Clash of Ignorance|url=http://www.thenation.com/article/clash-ignorance#|accessdate=27 February 2015|work=The Nation|date=4 October 2001}}</ref> In ''Covering Islam'', Said argued that "Lewis simply cannot deal with the diversity of Muslim, much less human life, because it is closed to him as something foreign, radically different, and other," and he criticised Lewis' "inability to grant that the Islamic peoples are entitled to their own cultural, political, and historical practices, free from Lewis' calculated attempt to show that because they are not Western... they can't be good."<ref name="said">{{cite book|last=Said|first=Edward|title=Covering Islam: how the media and the experts determine how we see the rest of the world|year=1997|publisher=Random House|location=New York|isbn=978-0-679-75890-7|pages=xxx–xxxi}}</ref>
Rejecting the view that Western scholarship was biased against the Middle East, Lewis responded that Orientalism developed as a facet of European [[humanism]], independently of the past European imperial expansion.<ref name="EH"/> He noted the French and English pursued the study of Islam in the 16th and 17th centuries, yet not in an organized way, but long before they had any control or hope of control in the Middle East; and that much of Orientalist study did nothing to advance the cause of imperialism. In his 1993 book ''Islam and the West'', Lewis wrote "What imperial purpose was served by deciphering the ancient Egyptian language, for example, and then restoring to the Egyptians knowledge of and pride in their forgotten, ancient past?"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lewis|first1=Bernard|title=Islam and the West|date=1993|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York City|isbn=978-0195090611|page=126}}</ref>
Furthermore, Lewis accused Said of politicizing the scientific study of the Middle East (and Arabic studies in particular); neglecting to critique the scholarly findings of the Orientalists; and giving "free rein" to his biases.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lewis|first1=Bernard|title=The Question of Orientalism|url=https://www.amherst.edu/media/view/307584/original/The+Question+of+Orientalism+by+Bernard+Lewis+%7C+The+New+York+Review+of+Books.pdf|publisher=New York Review of Books|accessdate=17 December 2017|date=24 June 1982}}</ref>
===Stance on the Iraq War=== In 2002, Lewis wrote an article for the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' regarding the buildup to the [[Iraq War]] entitled "Time for Toppling", where he stated his opinion that "a regime change may well be dangerous, but sometimes the dangers of inaction are greater than those of action".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Bernard|title=Time for Toppling|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB1033089910971012713|accessdate=24 February 2015|work=Wall Street Journal|date=27 September 2002}}</ref> In 2007, [[Jacob Weisberg]] described Lewis as "perhaps the most significant intellectual influence behind the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|invasion of Iraq]]".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2161800|title=AEI's Weird Celebration|first=Jacob|last=Weisberg|work=Slate Magazine|date=14 March 2007|accessdate=24 February 2015}}</ref> [[Michael Hirsh (journalist)|Michael Hirsh]] attributed to Lewis the view that regime change in Iraq would provide a jolt that would "modernize the Middle East" and suggested that Lewis' allegedly 'orientalist' theories about "what went wrong" in the Middle East, and other writings, formed the intellectual basis of the push towards war in Iraq. Hirsch reported that Lewis had told him in an interview that he viewed the [[September 11 attacks]] as "the opening salvo of the final battle" between Western and Islamic civilisations: Lewis believed that a forceful response was necessary. In the run up to the Iraq War, he met with Vice President [[Dick Cheney]] several times: Hirsch quoted an unnamed official who was present at a number of these meetings, who summarised Lewis' view of Iraq as "Get on with it. Don’t dither".<ref name=hirsch /> [[Brent Scowcroft]] quoted Lewis as stating that he believed "that one of the things you’ve got to do to Arabs is hit them between the eyes with a big stick. They respect power".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2005/10/31/breaking-ranks|title=Breaking Ranks |last=Goldberg |first=Jeffrey|author-link=Jeffrey Goldberg|date=31 October 2005|website=[[newyorker.com]]|access-date=30 June 2018}}</ref> As'ad AbuKhalil has claimed that Lewis assured Cheney that American troops would be welcomed by Iraqis and Arabs, relying on the opinion of his colleague [[Fouad Ajami]].<ref name=abukhalil>{{cite web |url=https://consortiumnews.com/2018/06/29/the-legacy-and-fallacies-of-bernard-lewis/|title=The Legacy and Fallacies of Bernard Lewis |last=AbuKhalil |first=As'ad|author-link=As'ad AbuKhalil |website=[[consortiumnews.com]] |access-date=30 June 2018}}</ref> Hirsch also drew parallels between the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]]'s plans for post-invasion Iraq and Lewis' views, in particular his admiration for [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]]'s [[Secularism|secularist]] and Westernising [[Atatürk's Reforms|reforms]] in the new [[History of the Republic of Turkey|Republic of Turkey]] which emerged from the collapse of the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref name=hirsch>{{cite news|last1=Hirsh |first1=Michael |title=Bernard Lewis Revisited |url=https://washingtonmonthly.com/2004/11/01/bernard-lewis-revisited/ |work=Washington Monthly |accessdate=24 February 2015 |date=November 2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108162236/http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/features/2004/0411.hirsh.html |archivedate=8 January 2014 |df= }}</ref>
Writing in 2008, Lewis did not advocate imposing freedom and democracy on Islamic nations. "There are things you can't impose. Freedom, for example. Or democracy. Democracy is a very strong medicine which has to be administered to the patient in small, gradually increasing doses. Otherwise, you risk killing the patient. In the main, the Muslims have to do it themselves."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leibowitz|first1=Ruthie Blum|title=One on One: When Defeat Means Liberation|url=http://www.jpost.com/Magazine/Features/One-on-One-When-defeat-means-liberation|accessdate=24 February 2015|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=6 March 2008}}</ref>
[[Ian Buruma]], writing for ''[[The New Yorker]]'' in an article subtitled "The two Minds of Bernard Lewis", finds Lewis's stance on the war difficult to reconcile with Lewis' past statements cautioning democracy enforcement in the world at large. Buruma ultimately rejects suggestions by his peers that Lewis promotes war with Iraq to safeguard Israel, but instead concludes "perhaps he loves it [the Arab world] too much":
{{quote|It is a common phenomenon among Western students of the Orient to fall in love with a civilization. Such love often ends in bitter impatience when reality fails to conform to the ideal. The rage, in this instance, is that of the Western scholar. His beloved civilization is sick. And what would be more heartwarming to an old Orientalist than to see the greatest Western democracy cure the benighted Muslim? It is either that or something less charitable: if a final showdown between the great religions is indeed the inevitable result of a millennial clash, then we had better make sure that we win.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Buruma|first1=Ian|title=Lost in Translation: The Two Minds of Bernard Lewis|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2004/06/14/lost-in-translation-3?currentPage=all|work=The New Yorker|accessdate=24 February 2015|date=14 June 2004}}</ref>}}
[[Hamid Dabashi]], writing on 28 May 2018, in an article subtitled "On Bernard Lewis and 'his extraordinary capacity for getting everything wrong'", asked: "Just imagine: What sort of a person would spend a lifetime studying people he loathes? It is quite a bizarre proposition. But there you have it: the late Bernard Lewis did precisely that." Similarly, [[Richard Bulliet]] described Lewis as "...a person who does not like the people he is purporting to have expertise about...he doesn’t respect them, he considers them to be good and worthy only to the degree they follow a Western path".<ref name=hirsch /> According to [[As'ad AbuKhalil]], "Lewis has poisoned the Middle East academic field more than any other Orientalist and his influence has been both academic and political. But there is a new generation of Middle East experts in the West who now see clearly the political agenda of Bernard Lewis. It was fully exposed in the Bush years."<ref>[https://english.al-akhbar.com/node/14409 Bernard Lewis and His Reputation] by As'ad AbuKhalil, 2012-12-17</ref>
===Alleged nuclear threat from Iran=== In 2006, Lewis wrote that [[Iran]] had been working on a [[Iranian nuclear program|nuclear weapon]] for fifteen years. In August 2006, in an article about whether the world can rely on the concept of [[mutual assured destruction]] as a deterrent in its dealings with Iran, Lewis wrote in the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' about the significance of 22 August 2006 in the [[Islamic calendar]]. The Iranian president had indicated he would respond by that date to U.S. demands regarding Iran's development of nuclear power. Lewis wrote that the date corresponded to the 27th day of the month of Rajab of the year 1427, the day Muslims commemorate the night flight of [[Muhammad]] from [[Jerusalem]] to heaven and back. Lewis wrote that it would be "an appropriate date for the apocalyptic ending of Israel and, if necessary, of the world".<ref name="August 22">{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Bernard|title=August 22|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB115500154638829470|accessdate=26 February 2015|work=Wall Street Journal|date=8 August 2006}}</ref>
According to Lewis, mutual assured destruction is not an effective deterrent in the case of Iran, because of what Lewis describes as the Iranian leadership's "apocalyptic worldview" and the "suicide or martyrdom complex that plagues parts of the Islamic world today".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Greene|first1=Thomas C.|title=Nuclear Holocaust Starts Today: ''WSJ''|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/08/21/iran_brings_it_on/|accessdate=26 February 2015|work=The Register|date=21 August 2006}}</ref> He then suggested the possibility of a nuclear strike on Israel on 22 August 2006: {{quote|What is the significance of Aug. 22? This year, Aug. 22 corresponds, in the Islamic calendar, to the 27th day of the month of Rajab of the year 1427. This, by tradition, is the night when many Muslims commemorate the night flight of Muhammad on the winged horse [[Buraq]], first to "the farthest mosque," usually identified with Jerusalem, and then to heaven and back{{Quran-usc|17|1|q=}}. This might well be deemed an appropriate date for the apocalyptic ending of Israel and if necessary of the world. It is far from certain that Mr. [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad|Ahmadinejad]] plans any such cataclysmic events precisely for 22 Aug.. But it would be wise to bear the possibility in mind.<ref name="August 22"/>}}
Lewis' article received significant press coverage.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Eslocker|first1=Asa|title=August 22: Doomsday?|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2006/08/is_tomorrow_doo/|accessdate=26 February 2015|work=ABC News|date=21 August 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Krieger|first1=Hilary Leila|title=Apocalypse Now?|url=http://www.jpost.com/Iranian-Threat/News/Apocalypse-now|accessdate=26 February 2015|work=Jerusalem Post|date=22 August 2006}}</ref> However, the day passed without any incident.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Greene|first1=Thomas C.|title=Nuclear Apocalypse Milder Than Expected: Back to the Ouija Board|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/08/23/lucky_to_be_alive/|accessdate=26 February 2015|work=The Register|date=23 August 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gawenda|first1=Michael|title=World Survives, But Solution on Iran is No Closer|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/world-survives-but-solution-on-iran-is-no-closer/2006/08/25/1156012739245.html|accessdate=26 February 2015|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=26 August 2006}}</ref><ref>[https://foreignpolicy.com/2006/08/30/one-week-and-still-no-nuclear-apocalypse/ One week…and still no nuclear apocalypse], Aditya Dasgupta, August 30, 2006, [[Foreign Policy]]</ref>
In his 2009 book ''Engaging the Muslim World'', the American academic [[Juan Cole]] responded that there was no evidence to suggest that Iran had been working on a nuclear weapon for fifteen years. He also disagreed with Lewis' suggestion that Ahmadinejad "might deploy this weapon against Israel on 22 August 2006".<ref>{{cite book|first=Juan|last=Cole|authorlink =Juan Cole|title=Engaging the Muslim World |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GPBmXHgWWU4C|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=GPBmXHgWWU4C&pg=PA205 205]|year=2009 |isbn=9780230620575}} </ref>
==Death== Bernard Lewis died on 19 May 2018 at the age of 101, at an assisted-living care facility in [[Voorhees Township, New Jersey]], twelve days before his 102nd birthday.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Murphy|first1=Brian|title=Bernard Lewis, eminent historian of the Middle East, dies at 101|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/bernard-lewis-eminent-historian-of-the-middle-east-dies-at-101/2018/05/19/4f0db6b8-5bad-11e8-8836-a4a123c359ab_story.html?noredirect=on|accessdate=19 May 2018|date=19 May 2018|newspaper=Washington Post}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Political anthropology|expanded=Basic concepts}}
A '''big man''' is a highly influential individual in a [[tribe]], especially in [[Melanesia]] and [[Polynesia]]. Such a person may not have formal tribal or other authority (through for instance material possessions, or inheritance of rights), but can maintain recognition through skilled persuasion and wisdom. The big man has a large group of followers, both from his [[clan]] and from other clans. He provides his followers with protection and economic assistance, in return receiving support which he uses to increase his status.
==Big man "system"==
The [[United States|American]] anthropologist [[Marshall Sahlins]] has studied the big man phenomenon. In his much-quoted<ref> James Whitley ("Social Diversity in Dark Age Greece", ''The Annual of the British School at Athens'' '''86''' (1991:341-365) applied Sahlins' ethnographic model to instability in settlement patterns during the [[Greek Dark Age]], 10th-8th centuries BCE. </ref> 1963 article "Poor Man, Rich Man, Big Man, Chief: Political Types in [[Melanesia]] and [[Polynesia]]", Sahlins uses analytically constructed ideal-types of hierarchy and equality to compare a larger-scale Polynesian-type hierarchical society of chiefs and sub-chiefs with a Melanesian-type big-man system.<ref>{{cite journal |URL=http://tapera.info/textos/sahlins,hrhp.pdf |author=Marshall Sahlins |title=Poor Man, Rich Man, Big Man, Chief; Political Types in Melanesia and Polynesia |journal=Comparative Studies in Society and History |volume=5 |number=3 |pages=285-303 |date=April 1963 |archive-date=1 January 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101000000/http://tapera.info/textos/sahlins,hrhp.pdf}}</ref>
The latter consists of segmented lineage groups, locally held together by faction-leaders who compete for power in the social structure of horizontally arranged and principally equal groupings (factions). Here, leadership is not ascribed, but rather gained through action and competition "with other ambitious men".
==Position== {{main|Moka exchange}} A big man's position is never secured in an inherited position at the top of a hierarchy, but is always challenged by the different big-men who compete with one another in an ongoing process of [[reciprocity (cultural anthropology)|reciprocity]] and re-distribution of material and political resources. As such the big man is subject to a [[Transactional analysis|transactional]] order based on his ability to balance the simultaneously opposing pulls of securing his own renown through distributing resources to other big man groups (thereby spreading the word of his power and abilities) ''and'' redistributing resources to the people of his own faction (thereby keeping them content followers of his able leadership).
The big man concept is relatively fluid, and formal authority of such figures is very low to nonexistent. His position is not inherently heritable.
In the Island of Malaita in Solomon Islands the big man system is dying away as westernization is influencing the people,{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} but the big man system can be seen at the political level. Every four years in [[Solomon Islands]]' National Elections the system can be clearly seen among the people, especially in the Melanesian Islands.{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}}
==System in Papua New Guinea== The first use of the term may be found in the English-translation of Dreissig Jahre in der Sudsee (1907) by [[Richard Parkinson (explorer)|Richard Parkinson]]. The term may be often found in many historical works dealing with Papua New Guinea. Andrew J. Strathern<ref>Strathern, ''The Rope of Moka: big-men and ceremonial exchange in Mount Hagen, Papua New Guinea'' (Cambridge, 1971)</ref> applies the concept of big-men to a community in [[Mount Hagen]], Papua New Guinea.
Traditionally, among peoples of non-[[Austronesian]]-speaking communities, authority was obtained by a man (the so-called "big man") recognised as "performing most capably in social, political, economic and ceremonial activities".<ref>Waiko, John D. (1993). ''A Short History of Papua New Guinea'', Melbourne: Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|0-19-553164-7}}, p.9</ref> His function was not to command, but to influence his society through his example. He was expected to act as a negotiator with neighbouring groups, and to periodically redistribute food (generally produced by his wives). In this sense, he was seen as ensuring the well-being of his community.
Such a system is still found in many parts of [[Papua New Guinea]], and other parts of [[Melanesia]].
==See also== *[[Moka exchange]] *[[Rom baro]] *[[Elder (administrative title)]] *[[Monarchy]] ==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *"The Big Men: Chris Bowler, Ben Smyth, Alex Thomas, and John Zhang." Essay by John Zhang in the 18th issue of ''Scroop''.
