{{advert|date=November 2018}} '''Viviane Namaste''' is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[feminism|feminist]] professor. The professor's research focuses on health and [[sex work]].<ref>{{cite web|url = https://thewalrus.ca/author/viviane-namaste/|title = On Women, Vice and Vagrancy in Canada|publisher = Walrus TV|date = 2015-01-29|accessdate = 2015-10-17}}</ref>
==Biography== Namaste graduated from [[Carleton University]] in 1989 with a BA and continued her education at [[York University]], earning an MA in [[Sociology]]. She then completed her doctoral at [[Université du Québec à Montréal]] in Semiotics and [[Linguistics]].<ref name="concordia1">{{cite web|author= |url=http://artsandscience.concordia.ca/research/researchchairs/concordiaresearchchairs/drvivianenamaste/ |title=Dr. Viviane Namaste - Faculty of Arts and Science - Concordia University - Montreal, Quebec, Canada |publisher=Artsandscience.concordia.ca |date= |accessdate=2015-10-17}}</ref><ref name=Hour>{{cite web|last1=Burnett|first1=Richard|title=Hot Shots: Professor Viviane Namaste: Viviane Namaste|url=http://hour.ca/2009/08/20/viviane-namaste/|publisher=[[Hour Community]]|accessdate=20 October 2015|location=Montreal, Quebec, Canada|date=20 August 2009}}</ref> She worked within [[ACT UP]] Paris.<ref name=Hour /> In 2001, she received the Outstanding Book Award from the [[Gustavus Myers Center#Death and legacy|Gustavus Myers Center]] for her book entitled, ''Invisible Lives: The Erasure of Transsexual and Transgendered People''.<ref name=awards>{{cite web|title=2009 Canadian Recipient: Viviane Namaste|url=http://www.aidslaw.ca/site/our-story/award-for-action/past-recipients/#VNamaste|publisher=AIDs Law Canada|accessdate=20 October 2015|location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada|date=2014}}</ref> That same year, Namaste was also a director in the documentary ''Madame Lauraine's Transsexual Touch'' which deals with transsexual sex workers as well as sexual health and clientele.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemapolitica.org/es/node/1900 |title=Madame Lauraine's Transsexual Touch |publisher=cinema politica |date= |accessdate=2015-10-17}}</ref>
Namaste became an associate professor and the Research Chair in HIV/AIDS and Sexual Health at [[Concordia University]] in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.<ref name=awards /> In 2009, she was awarded the "Canadian Award for Action on HIV/AIDS and Human Rights", which is awarded jointly by the Canadian HIV/AIDS Legal Network and [[Human Rights Watch]].<ref name="Daily Xtra">{{cite news|last1=Syms|first1=Shawn|title=Trans academic wins human rights award|url=http://www.dailyxtra.com/canada/news-and-ideas/news/trans-academic-wins-human-rights-award-52561|accessdate=20 October 2015|publisher=Daily Xtra|date=12 July 2009|location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada}}</ref>
In 2012, Namaste led a strike with SDBI faculty in order to protest tuition increases.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://thelinknewspaper.ca/article/wssa-to-strike-a-second-week|title = Institute Sends Ministry of Education Invitation for Debate|last = Beeston|first = Laura|date = 10 March 2012|work = The Link|access-date = 19 October 2015|via = }}</ref><ref name="Journal Metro">{{cite news|last1=Chevalier|first1=Andréanne|title=Luttes sociales, luttes féministes|url=http://journalmetro.com/actualites/national/293565/luttes-sociales-luttes-feministes/|accessdate=20 October 2015|publisher=Journal Metro|date=16 April 2013|location=Montreal, Quebec, Canada|language=French}}</ref> In 2013, she was called as an official intervenor in a hearing at the [[Supreme Court of Canada]]<ref name="CBC News">{{cite news|title=Montreal prof seeks Supreme Court ruling on sex work|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/montreal-prof-seeks-supreme-court-ruling-on-sex-work-1.1317081|accessdate=20 October 2015|publisher=CBC News|date=13 June 2013|location=Montreal, Quebec, Canada}}</ref> on whether the ban on [[solicitation]], prohibition of [[brothels]] and criminality of making a living from prostitution violate the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|Charter of Rights]].<ref name="violation of rights">{{cite news|last1=la Reine|first1=Bedford C.|title=Procès: décriminalisation de la prostitution à l'ordre du jour|url=http://www.lapresse.ca/actualites/justice-et-affaires-criminelles/201306/12/01-4660359-proces-decriminalisation-de-la-prostitution-a-lordre-du-jour.php|accessdate=20 October 2015|publisher=La Presse|date=13 June 2013|location=Montreal, Quebec, Canada}}</ref>
The [[Feminism|feminist]] journal, ''[[Hypatia: A Journal of Feminist Philosophy|Hypatia]]'', has called Namaste's work, "extremely important".<ref name=":1" /> Namaste considers [[activism]] more important than work within the [[humanities]].<ref>{{Cite journal|url = https://muse.jhu.edu/journals/esc_english_studies_in_canada/v035/35.2-3.crawford.html|title = Re-Fashioning the Architectonics of Gender|last = Crawford|first = Lucas|date = 2009|journal = ESC: English Studies in Canada|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 19 October 2015|subscription = yes|volume = 35|issue = 2|pages = 18–23}}</ref>
==Published work==
;''Imprimés interdits : La censure des journaux jaunes au Québec, 1955-1975'' In post-war Quebec, a new form of popular communication emerged: the "yellow newspapers", so named because of the poor quality of their paper. It contained all the gossip about artists, cabarets and nightlife, with content strongly dominated by sexuality.<ref>[https://www.septentrion.qc.ca/catalogue/imprimes-interdits Septentrion, 2017.]</ref>
;''Invisible Lives: The Erasure of Transsexual and Transgendered People'' ''Invisible Lives'' evaluates the erasure of transgender individuals by medical psychiatry.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=lfh&AN=3765689&site=ehost-live|title = Invisible Lives (Book Review)|last = Ingram|first = Jeff|date = November 2000|journal = Library Journal|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 19 October 2015|volume = 125|issue = 18|page = 120|subscription = yes}}</ref> It also draws on the daily lived-experiences of transgendered individuals and describes how their identity permeates every facet of their life from obtaining housing to health care.<ref name=":0" /> The ''[[Library Journal]]'' wrote that ''Invisible Lives'' has "broken new ground with one of the first sociological studies of the TS/TG community."<ref name=":0" />
;''Sex Change, Social Change: Reflections on Identity, Institutions, and Imperialism'' This book utilizes case studies as a means to analyze elements such as [[Human rights]] and [[Prostitution]] in looking at transsexual politics in [[Quebec]] and [[Canada]]. Namaste asks what makes someone a woman and whether male to female transsexuals should be included in women's spaces.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=lfh&AN=27728691&site=ehost-live|title = Sex Change, Social Change: Reflections on Identity, Institutions, and Imperialism|last = Hale|first = C. Jacob|date = 2008|journal = Hypatia|doi = 10.2979/hyp.2008.23.1.204|pmid = |access-date = 19 October 2015|volume = 23|issue = 1|pages = 204–207|subscription = yes}}</ref> Namaste also explores how gender and sex are defined in our culture and discusses the everyday manner in which transsexuals face discrimination.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|url = http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=35664422&site=ehost-live|title = Getting Past Identity: A Fresh Look at Issues in Transsexuality|last = Poole|first = Katherine M.|date = 2008|journal = Canadian Dimension|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 19 October 2015|subscription = yes|issue = 6|page = 42|volume = 42}}</ref> In the end, she recommends that feminists "integrate transsexual politics and theory into their work."<ref name=":1" /> One criticism that the journal, ''[[Hypatia: A Journal of Feminist Philosophy|Hypatia]]'', makes of the writing in ''Sex Change, Social Change'' is that Namaste is "at times antagonistic towards transsexual and transgender activists and theorists who work within gay, lesbian, or queer frameworks."<ref name=":1" /> ''[[Canadian Dimension]]'' writes that her book makes the subject matter "accessible to those unacquainted with the current body of work on transsexuality."<ref name=":2" />
;''C'était du spectacle! L'histoire des artistes transsexuelles à Montréal, 1955-1985'' This book explores the lives of fourteen transsexual cabaret dancers.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|url = https://muse.jhu.edu/journals/university_of_toronto_quarterly/v077/77.1.boisclair.html|title = C'était du spectacle. L'histoire des artistes transsexuelles à Montréal 1955-1985 (review)|last = Boisclair|first = Isabelle|date = 2008|journal = University of Toronto Quarterly|doi = 10.1353/utq.0.0002|pmid = |access-date = 19 October 2015|subscription = yes|volume = 77|issue = 1|pages = 639–641|language = French}}</ref> It discusses how transsexuals and transvestites were largely responsible for [[Cabaret]]'s culture.<ref name=":4" /> Looking at the social changes that occurred in the 60's and 70's in Quebec, this book examines working conditions for these cabaret dancers as well as police abuse of power.<ref name=":4" />

The '''Wiesbaden manifesto''' is a document written and signed by members of the [[Monuments, Fine Arts and Archives]] (MFAA) organization rejecting the plundering and removal of cultural items as spoils of war. The Allies created special commissions, such as the MFAA, to help protect famous European monuments from destruction, and after the war, to travel to territories previously occupied by the Germans to find Nazi art repositories. The allies found these plundered artworks in over 1,050 repositories in Germany and [[Austria]] at the end of [[World War II]]. The book ''The Safekeepers: Memoir of the Arts at the End of World War II'' by former [[Walter Farmer|Capt. Walter I. Farmer]] of the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] during World War II, chronicles the recovery of and restitution of discovered hidden loot of the [[Nazi plunder]], that were stolen from museums, private collections and libraries and individual [[Jewish]] emigrants and [[death camp]] prisoners.<ref>The Safekeepers: A Memoir of the Arts at the End of World War II By Walter Ings Farmer, Klaus Goldmann Published by Walter de Gruyter, 2000 {{ISBN|978-3-11-016897-6}}, 242 pages</ref>
In summer 1945, Capt. Walter Farmer became the collecting point's first director. The first shipment of artworks arriving at Wiesbaden included cases of antiquities, Egyptian art, Islamic artifacts, and paintings from the [[Kaiser Friedrich Museum]]. The collecting point also received materials from the [[Reichsbank]] and [[Nazi]] looted [[Poles|Polish]] liturgical collections. At its height, Wiesbaden stored, identified, and restituted approximately 700,000 individual objects, including paintings and sculptures.<ref>http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.php?id=10388</ref> The collecting point not only cataloged and restitutued items, but also kept them away from the [[Soviet Army]] and wartime reparations.<ref>http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.php?id=10388</ref><ref>Opritsa D. Popa. Bibliophiles and Bibliothieves: The Search for the Hildebrandslied and the Willehalm Codex. Berlin and New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2003. xvi + 265 pp. $58.00 (cloth), {{ISBN|978-3-11-017730-5}}</ref>
When his superiors ordered that he send to the U.S. 202 German-owned paintings in his custody, Capt. Farmer and 35 others who were in charge of the Wiesbaden collection point gathered to draw up what has become known as the Wiesbaden Manifesto on November 7, 1945, declaring "We wish to state that, from our own knowledge, no historical grievance will rankle so long or be the cause of so much justified bitterness as the removal for any reason of a part of the heritage of any nation even if that heritage may be interpreted as a prize of war." Among the co-signers was Lieutenant [[Charles Percy Parkhurst]] of the U.S. Navy.<ref>Walter I. Farmer. The Safekeepers: A Memoir of the Arts at the End of World War II. Berlin and New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2000. x + 242 pp., {{ISBN|978-3-11-016897-6}}</ref>
After three years of debate, U.S. President [[Harry S. Truman]] ordered that the paintings be returned to Germany in 1948.

{{Infobox writer | name = Yaa Gyasi | image = Yaa Gyasi, 9 27 (36709389003) (cropped).jpg | birth_date = 1989 | birth_place = [[Mampong, Ghana]] | education = [[Stanford University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[University of Iowa]] {{small|([[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]])}} | awards = {{bullet list|[[National Book Critics Circle Award|National Book Critics Circle]]'s [[National Book Critics Circle Award#John Leonard Award|John Leonard Award]]|[[Hemingway Foundation/PEN Award|PEN/Hemingway Award]]|[[National Book Foundation]]'s "[[National Book Foundation#5 Under 35|5 under 35]]"}} }} '''Yaa Gyasi''' (born 1989) is a Ghanaian-American novelist. Her [[debut novel]], [[Homegoing (2016 novel)|''Homegoing'']], published in 2016, won her, at the age of 26, the [[National Book Critics Circle Award|National Book Critics Circle]]'s [[National Book Critics Circle Award#John Leonard Award|John Leonard Award]] for best first book, the [[Hemingway Foundation/PEN Award|PEN/Hemingway Award]] for a first book of fiction, the [[National Book Foundation]]'s "[[National Book Foundation#5 Under 35|5 under 35]]" honors for 2016 and the [[American Book Award]]. == Early life and education == Born in [[Mampong|Mampong, Ghana]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/homegoing-by-yaa-gyasi-born-in-ghana-and-raised-in-the-u-s-1464273302|title=''Homegoing'' by Yaa Gyasi, Born in Ghana and Raised in the U.S.|last=Maloney|first=Jennifer|date=May 26, 2016|work=|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=December 2, 2016|via=}} she is the daughter of Kwaku Gyasi, a professor of French at the [[University of Alabama in Huntsville]], and Sophia, who is a nurse.{{Cite news|url=http://www.uah.edu/news/people/uah-welcomes-yaa-gyasi-author-of-the-new-york-times-best-selling-book-homegoing|title=UAH welcomes Yaa Gyasi, author of ''The New York Times'' best-selling book ''Homegoing''|last=Anderson-Maples|first=Joyce|date=December 2, 2016|publisher=The University of Alabama in Huntsville|access-date=December 2, 2016|via=}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.al.com/opinion/index.ssf/2016/08/how_an_alabama_womans_debut_no.html|title=How an Alabama author's debut novel landed her on 'The Daily Show'|last=Haskin|first=Shelly|date=August 28, 2016|newspaper=AL.com|access-date=December 4, 2016}} Her family moved to the United States in 1991 when her father was completing his Ph.D. at [[Ohio State University]].{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4357214/homegoing-yaa-gyasi-profile/|title=A 26-Year-old Looks to the Past for Her Literary Debut|last=Begley|first=Sarah|website=TIME.com|date=June 5, 2016|access-date=December 2, 2016}} The family also lived in [[Illinois]] and [[Tennessee]], and from the age of 10, Gyasi was raised in [[Huntsville, Alabama]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalbook.org/5under35_2016_yaa-gyasi.html|title=Yaa Gyasi, author of ''Homegoing'', 5 Under 35, 2016, National Book Foundation|last=|first=|date=|website=www.nationalbook.org|publisher=|access-date=December 2, 2016}} Gyasi recalls being shy as a child, feeling close to her brothers for their shared experiences as young immigrant children in Alabama, and turning to books as her "closest friends". She received a certificate of achievement signed by [[LeVar Burton]] after submitting the first story she wrote to the [[PBS Kids Writers Contest|Reading Rainbow Young Writers and Illustrators Contest]], which encouraged her, and after reading [[Toni Morrison]]'s [[Song of Solomon (novel)|''Song of Solomon'']] while attending [[Grissom High School]] at the age of 17, she was inspired to choose a career in writing. She earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in English at [[Stanford University|Stanford]], and a [[Master of Fine Arts]] from the [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]], a creative writing program at the [[University of Iowa]].{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/books/article/How-Yaa-Gyasi-found-her-story-in-slavers-8329849.php |title=How Yaa Gyasi found her story in slavers' outpost |author=Wolfe, Eli |date=June 28, 2016 |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=March 1, 2017}} ==Career== Shortly after graduating from Stanford, she began her debut novel and worked at a startup company in San Francisco, but she did not enjoy the work and resigned after she was accepted to Iowa in 2012. Her debut novel ''[[Homegoing (Gyasi novel)|Homegoing]]'' was inspired by a 2009 trip to Ghana, Gyasi's first since leaving the country as an infant. The novel was completed in 2015, and after initial readings from publishers, was met with numerous offers before she accepted a seven-figure advance from [[Alfred A. Knopf|Knopf]]. [[Ta-Nehisi Coates]] selected ''Homegoing'' for the National Book Foundation's 2016 "5 under 35" award, and the novel also was selected for the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Award, the [[Hemingway Foundation/PEN Award|PEN/Hemingway award]] for best first book, and the American Book Award for contributions to diversity in American literature.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/aug/4/debut-novelist-among-winners-of-american-book-awar/|title=Debut novelist among winners of American Book Awards|last=|first=|date=August 4, 2017|work=The Washington Times|access-date=|author=Associated Press|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}Alter, Alexandra, [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/17/arts/zadie-smith-and-michael-chabon-among-national-book-critics-circle-finalists.html?_r=0 "Zadie Smith and Michael Chabon Among National Book Critics Circle Finalists"], ''New York Times'', January 17, 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pen-ne.org/hemingway/|title=PEN/Hemingway Award for Debut Fiction|last=|first=|date=|website=PEN New England|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=April 23, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/23/books/review/100-notable-books-of-2016.html|title=100 Notable Books of 2016|date=November 21, 2016|access-date=December 2, 2016|issn=0362-4331|newspaper=The New York Times}} Her writing has also appeared in such publications as ''[[African American Review]]'',[http://aar.slu.edu/current.html ''AAR''] ''African American Review. ''[[Callaloo (journal)|Callaloo]]'',[https://www.loc.gov/bookfest/author/yaa_gyasi "Yaa Gyasi"], National Book Festival, Library of Congress. ''[[Guernica (magazine)|Guernica]]''Yaa Gyasi, [https://www.guernicamag.com/inscape/ "Inscape"], ''Guernica'', June 15, 2015. ''[[The Guardian]]'',[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/oct/28/yaa-gyasi-my-writing-day "Yaa Gyasi: ‘I write a sentence. I delete it. I wonder if it’s too early for lunch’"], ''The Guardian'', October 28, 2017. and ''[[Granta]]''.Gyasi, Yaa, [https://granta.com/leaving-gotham-city/ "Leaving Gotham City"], ''Granta 139: Best of Young American Novelists'' 3, April 25, 2017. Gyasi cites [[Toni Morrison]] ([[Song of Solomon (novel)|''Song of Solomon'']]), [[Gabriel García Márquez]] (''[[One Hundred Years of Solitude]]''), [[James Baldwin]] ([[Go Tell It on the Mountain (novel)|''Go Tell It on the Mountain'']]), [[Edward P. Jones]] (''[[Lost in the City]]''), and [[Jhumpa Lahiri]] (''[[Unaccustomed Earth]]'') as inspirations.{{cite web |url=https://www.penguin.co.uk/articles/find-your-next-read/five-books/2017/jan/books-that-influenced-yaa-gyasi/ |title=Five books: The books that influenced Yaa Gyasi |author= |date=2016 |publisher=Penguin |accessdate=March 1, 2017}} {{as of|2016}}, Gyasi lives in [[Berkeley, California]]. ==Works== * [[Homegoing (2016 novel)|''Homegoing'']] (2016) ==Awards== * [[National Book Critics Circle Award|National Book Critics Circle]]'s [[National Book Critics Circle Award#John Leonard Award|John Leonard Award]] for best first book * [[Hemingway Foundation/PEN Award|PEN/Hemingway Award]] for a first book of fiction * 2016: [[National Book Foundation]]'s "[[National Book Foundation#5 Under 35|5 under 35]] * [[American Book Award]] * 2017: ''[[Granta]]'' Best of Young American NovelistsKellogg, Carolyn, and Michael Schaub, [http://beta.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-et-jc-granta-best-young-american-novelists-20170426-story.html "Granta names 21 of the best young American novelists"], ''The Los Angeles Times'', April 26, 2017.[https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/apr/26/granta-list-best-young-american-novelists "Granta’s list of the best young American novelists"], ''The Guardian'', April 26, 2017.Onwuemezi, Natasha, [https://www.thebookseller.com/news/granta-best-542896 "Granta reveals its Best of Young US Novelists 2017"], ''[[The Bookseller]]'', April 26, 2017. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{commons cat}} * ''NYT SundayReview'' Opinion by Yaa Gyasi, [http://nyti.ms/1Y1ngOp "I'm Ghanaian-American. Am I Black?"] June 8, 2016 * [http://www.cc.com/video-clips/3rbep4/the-daily-show-with-trevor-noah-yaa-gyasi---connecting-african-and-american-history-in--homegoing- Interview on the ''Daily Show'' with Trevor Noah] (video, 5:43), August 16, 2016 * [http://www.nbc.com/late-night-with-seth-meyers/video/author-yaa-gyasi-on-writing-homegoing/3078618 Interview on ''Late Night'' with Seth Meyers] (video, 3:15), August 2, 2016 * [https://www.pbs.org/wnet/tavissmiley/interviews/author-yaa-gyasi/ Interview on Tavis Smiley] (video, 11:34) and transcript, June 2, 2016 * [[Kate Kellaway]], [https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/jan/08/yaa-gyasi-slavery-is-on-peoples-minds-it-affects-us-still-interview-homegoing-observer-new-review "Yaa Gyasi: ‘Slavery is on people’s minds. It affects us still’"], ''The Guardian'', January 8, 2017. * [http://www.foyles.co.uk/Author-Yaa-Gyasi "Yaa Gyasi"] at Foyles. * Alec Russell, [https://www.ft.com/content/c616da96-4311-11e8-93cf-67ac3a6482fd "Yaa Gyasi: ‘Racism is still the drumbeat of America’"], April 20, 2018. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gyasi, Yaa}} [[Category:21st-century American novelists]] [[Category:21st-century American women writers]] [[Category:American women novelists]] [[Category:Iowa Writers' Workshop alumni]] [[Category:Ghanaian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Ghanaian women novelists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Race in the United States]] [[Category:Slave trade]] [[Category:Women historical novelists]] [[Category:American Book Award winners]] [[Category:1989 births]] [[Category:21st-century Ghanaian women writers]] [[Category:21st-century Ghanaian writers]] [[Category:African-American women writers]] [[Category:African-American writers]]
